pageContext.claim: “Over the last 15 years, we've seen a continual decline in the U.S. share of agricultural trade all throughout the world.”
pageContext.analysis: This statement requires context. In the last 15 years, developing nations have gained a larger share of agricultural trade, though the percentage held by North America has declined only slightly, according to USDA. Meanwhile, U.S. agricultural exports grew steadily over the last two decades, reaching $140.47 billion in 2017, from $56.2 billion in 1995. Moreover, the United States has maintained a surplus in agricultural trade since 1960, which the agency says has helped counter the persistent deficit in nonagricultural U.S. merchandise trade.
